title: "The Power of Fascination: Understanding its Uses and Effects"
first_phrase: In the previous section, we discussed the concept of "Fascination" - the ability of enchanting eyes to affect a person's body, spirit, and emotions. Giordano Bruno argued that this power comes from the purest blood generated by a lucid and subtle heart. In this last section, we see an example of someone who literally "petrified" his subjects with his gaze - Virgilio T. - which illustrates the potency of this hidden force.
content: Ahora se llega espíritu a espíritu, y la luz superior, in-calculando la inferior, vienen a centellar por los ojos, corriendo y penetrando el espíritu interno, que está radicado en el corazón, y así conmueven amado incendio. Pero quien no quiere ser fascinado, debe estar máximamente cauto, y realizar buena guardia en los ojos, los cuales en acto de amor principalmente son las ventanas del alma: donde esta aquel dicho: Averte, averte oculos tuos!! [6] ¡Esto para el presente es suficiente! “ Giordano Bruno[7] “Fascinación” es el término técnico para indicar la capacidad de ojos hechiceros... La imagen de la Medusa que petrifica con su mirada es seguramente el traslado metafórico de tal realidad. Corresponde a las acciones que podemos observar en Virgilio T. que literalmente “dejaba como estatuas” a sus sujetos.
last_phrase: In conclusion, it is important to be cautious of the power of the gaze and the potential for fascination. As Giordano Bruno suggests, we must guard our eyes, as they are the windows to our souls. The phenomenon of being immobilized by a gaze, like that of Virgilio T., is a real and understandable reaction of the brain, similar to the stupefaction of animals when confronted with bright light. However, with knowledge and awareness, we can protect ourselves from becoming figurative “statues” and enjoy mosquito-free summer evenings.
